The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified. Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified. Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines. They will investigate the code fragments you give. Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule. Provide your answer with these fields. - suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code. It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags - explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated. It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated. DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments. Here is the code of list_directory: ```c static enum MHD_Result list_directory (struct ResponseDataContext *rdc, const char *dirname) { char fullname[PATH_MAX]; struct stat sbuf; DIR *dir; struct dirent *de; if (NULL == (dir = opendir (dirname))) return MHD_NO; while (NULL != (de = readdir (dir))) { int res; if ('.' == de->d_name[0]) continue; if (sizeof (fullname) <= (unsigned int) snprintf (fullname, sizeof (fullname), "%s/%s", dirname, de->d_name)) continue; /* ugh, file too long? how can this be!? */ if (0 != stat (fullname, &sbuf)) continue; /* ugh, failed to 'stat' */ if (! S_ISREG (sbuf.st_mode)) continue; /* not a regular file, skip */ if (rdc->off + 1024 > rdc->buf_len) { void *r; if ( (2 * rdc->buf_len + 1024) < rdc->buf_len) break; /* more than SIZE_T _index_ size? Too big for us */ rdc->buf_len = 2 * rdc->buf_len + 1024; if (NULL == (r = realloc (rdc->buf, rdc->buf_len))) break; /* out of memory */ rdc->buf = r; } res = snprintf (&rdc->buf[rdc->off], rdc->buf_len - rdc->off, "
  • %s
    • \n", fullname, de->d_name); if (0 >= res) continue; /* snprintf() error */ if (rdc->buf_len - rdc->off <= (size_t) res) continue; /* buffer too small?? */ rdc->off += (size_t) res; } (void) closedir (dir); return MHD_YES; } ```     Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter itself is modified in this function. The parameters are:
- struct ResponseDataContext *rdc — only members of *rdc are written (rdc->buf_len, rdc->buf, rdc->off); modifying the object pointed to is permitted by Rule 17.8. There is no assignment to the pointer variable rdc itself (no statement like "rdc = ..."), no pointer arithmetic on rdc, and no cast that would modify the pointer parameter.
- const char *dirname — it is only read (passed to opendir/stat/snprintf); it is not written to or reassigned. There is no cast away of const to modify its pointee.
Other local pointers (dir, de, r) are local variables and not function parameters, so their modification does not affect Rule 17.8. Therefore no code fragments require further investigation for Rule 17.8.
